title: 109_s1390
content: The Act titled "Coral Reef Conservation Amendments Act of 2005" expands the Coral Reef Conservation Program. The Coral Reef Conservation Act of 2000 is amended to prioritize funding for projects addressing emerging priorities or threats, including international and territorial concerns, as well as other appropriate projects like monitoring, research, pollution reduction, education, and technical support. The Coral Reef Conservation Act of 2000 is amended to prioritize funding for projects addressing emerging priorities or threats, including international and territorial concerns, as well as other appropriate projects like monitoring, research, pollution reduction, education, and technical support. Additionally, amendments are made to promote activities to minimize vessel impacts on coral reefs and support community-based planning and management initiatives for the protection of coral reef systems. SEC. 3. EMERGENCY RESPONSE. Amendment to prioritize funding for projects addressing emerging priorities or threats, including international concerns. The Administrator is authorized to take emergency response actions to protect coral reefs from various threats, including vessel impacts and disaster-related damage. This may involve vessel removal and partnering with other federal agencies for resources and support. SEC. 4 of the Coral Reef Conservation Act of 2000 is amended to include activities to minimize vessel impacts on coral reefs. SEC. 5 involves reporting to Congress on coral reef conservation efforts. The Administrator must submit a report every 3 years to Congress detailing activities to implement coral reef conservation efforts, including funds allocated by federal agencies and collaborative projects with states and territories to address anthropogenic impacts on coral reefs. The report to Congress must include information on the vessel grounding inventory, Federal disaster response actions for coral reefs, and the assessment of coral reef conditions and management effectiveness under the Coral Reef Conservation Act of 2000. SEC. 6. FUND; GRANTS; GROUNDING INVENTORY; COORDINATION. The Coral Reef Conservation Act of 2000 is amended to support partnerships between public and private sectors, address emergency response actions, and encourage funding from the private sector for activities to prevent damage to coral reefs. The Coral Reef Conservation Act of 2000 is amended to support partnerships between public and private sectors, address emergency response actions, and encourage funding from the private sector for activities to prevent damage to coral reefs. The amendments include redesignating sections and inserting new sections related to grant programs and emergency response actions. "SEC. 209. COMMUNITY-BASED PLANNING GRANTS." The Administrator may provide grants to entities previously funded under section 204(c) to assist local communities in preparing and implementing plans for the protection of high-priority coral reef areas. Plans must align with specified criteria, involve community-level development, use watershed-based approaches, coordinate with experts, and incorporate local resource management concepts. The provisions of subsections (b), (d), (f), and (h) of section 204 apply to grants under subsection (a), with a modification that '75 percent' is substituted for '50 percent' in section 204(b)(1). "Section 210 discusses the Vessel Grounding Inventory." The Administrator may maintain an inventory of vessel grounding incidents involving coral reef resources, including impacts, vessel information, cost estimates, response actions, status, and recommendations for prevention. Additionally, the Administrator may identify at-risk reefs. The Administrator may identify coral reef areas outside designated National Marine Sanctuaries with high vessel impact incidence and implement measures to reduce such impacts. The Administrator will collaborate with other agencies, states, and territorial governments to implement strategies to protect coral reefs from threats like coastal runoff and overharvesting. This includes regional and local strategies. The table of contents for the Coral Reef Conservation Act is amended to include sections on community-based planning grants, vessel grounding inventory, and regional coordination. Authorization of appropriations is also addressed. Section 212 of the Coral Reef Conservation Act of 2000 is amended to increase funding for fiscal years 2006 through 2012, with specific allocations for grant programs and the establishment of a Fund. Additionally, the amendment authorizes an increase in funding for community-based planning grants. Additionally, funding for community-based planning grants is authorized at $8,000,000 for fiscal years 2007 through 2012. The Coral Reef Conservation Act of 2000 was amended to increase funding for grant programs and establish a Fund. Passed by the Senate on December 15, 2005.
